articles.headline: Safety Is Issue as Budget Cuts Free Prisoners
articles.snippet: Complaints and new arrests have prompted some states to reconsider giving prisoners time off for good behavior.
articles.abstract: Complaints and new arrests have prompted some states to reconsider giving prisoners time off for good behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the rush to save money in grim budgetary times, states nationwide have trimmed their prison populations by expanding parole programs and early releases. But the result — more convicted felons on the streets, not behind bars — has unleashed a backlash, and state officials now find themselves trying to maneuver between saving money and maintaining the public’s sense of safety.

articles.headline: House Adopts $15 Billion Plan to Spur Job Growth
articles.snippet: The measure, granting payroll tax breaks for new hires, was called the first step in a broad push on the economy.
articles.abstract: The measure, granting payroll tax breaks for new hires, was called the first step in a broad push on the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday approved a $15 billion measure intended to spur job creation by granting tax breaks to businesses that hire workers, as Democrats, bracing for new jobless figures, tried to show that Congress was doing something about stubborn unemployment.

articles.headline: Closing of Rest Stops Stirs Anger in Arizona
articles.snippet: The state’s decision to close 13 highway rest stops has been met with more anger than other cost-cutting moves.
articles.abstract: The state’s decision to close 13 highway rest stops has been met with more anger than other cost-cutting moves.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The people of Arizona kept their upper lips stiff when officials mortgaged off the state’s executive office tower and a “Daily Show” crew rolled into town to chronicle the transaction in mocking tones. They remained calm as lawmakers pondered privatizing death row.

articles.headline: The Newest Hybrid Model
articles.snippet: A vast project in Florida will be the world’s second-largest solar plant, attached to the nation’s largest fossil-fuel power plant.
articles.abstract: A vast project in Florida will be the world’s second-largest solar plant, attached to the nation’s largest fossil-fuel power plant.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANTOWN, Fla. — In former swamplands teeming with otters and wild hogs, one of the nation’s biggest utilities is running an experiment in the future of renewable power.

articles.headline: Market Defies Fear of Real Estate Bubble in China
articles.snippet: China’s spectacular real estate boom may be a bubble  that threatens the global economy.
articles.abstract: China’s spectacular real estate boom may be a bubble  that threatens the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The spacious duplex comes with crocodile-skin bedposts, hand-carved bronze doors inlaid with Swarovski crystals — and a $45 million price tag.

articles.headline: For Greece, Bond Sale Is a Step Back From Disaster
articles.snippet: By completing a long-awaited bond sale, Greece gave a lift to its embattled government finances and bolstered other peripheral European countries that share the euro.
articles.abstract: By completing a long-awaited bond sale, Greece gave a lift to its embattled government finances and bolstered other peripheral European countries that share the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — After pledging to mend its profligate ways, Greece took a crucial step on Thursday toward raising the billions needed to pay its bills and contain the crisis threatening the euro.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and David Jolly

articles.headline: A Game of Resisting the I.R.S.
articles.snippet: The agency wants to require companies to disclose the tax games they are playing and the maximum tax hit they could take if the I.R.S. challenged them.
articles.abstract: The agency wants to require companies to disclose the tax games they are playing and the maximum tax hit they could take if the I.R.S. challenged them.
articles.lead_paragraph: If ever there was an area of taxation that needed simplification, it is the American corporate income tax. Companies end up filing tax returns containing thousands, or even tens of thousands, of pages.

articles.headline: Rash of Scandals Tests Democrats at Sensitive Time
articles.snippet: Ethics cases have opened the party to the same lines of criticism used against Republicans in winning control of the House and Senate four years ago.
articles.abstract: Ethics cases have opened the party to the same lines of criticism used against Republicans in winning control of the House and Senate four years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The ethical woes facing Democrats are piling up, with barely a day passing in recent weeks without headlines from Washington to New York and beyond filled with word of scandal or allegations of wrongdoing.

articles.headline: For Psychic, Suit Came as Surprise
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Sean David Morton, who said he could foretell the stock market’s direction, of swindling $6 million.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Sean David Morton, who said he could foretell the stock market’s direction, of swindling $6 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: He calls himself “America’s Prophet,” a psychic, trained by Nepalese monks in the art of time travel, who can foretell the future of the stock market.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: I.M.F. Help for Greece Is a Risky Prospect
articles.snippet: If Greece asks the International Monetary Fund for help, it could touch off political and financial tension in other European countries.
articles.abstract: If Greece asks the International Monetary Fund for help, it could touch off political and financial tension in other European countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greece skirted disaster this week by persuading investors and politicians that it is finally on track to fix its finances. But even before the dust settles, the government is setting the stage for a potential conflict with Germany, France and other European governments that may raise doubts about the sustainability of the euro project.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Jobless Rate Holds Steady, Raising Hopes of Recovery
articles.snippet: The economy in February shed 36,000 nonfarm jobs, fewer than forecast, as the unemployment rate held at 9.7 percent, the Labor Department said on Friday.
articles.abstract: The economy in February shed 36,000 nonfarm jobs, fewer than forecast, as the unemployment rate held at 9.7 percent, the Labor Department said on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy lost fewer jobs than expected last month, bolstering hopes that the worst may finally be over in the wrenching event known as the Great Recession.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Javier C. Hernández
